problem: Four positive integers $A$, $B$, $C$ and $D$ have a sum of 64. If $A+3 = B-3 = C \times 3 = D \div 3$, what is the value of the product $A \times B \times C \times D$?
solution: We have that $A + B + C + D = 64$.  Substituting everything in terms of $C$, we find that $(3C - 3) + (3C + 3) + C + (9C) = 64$, which means that $C = 4$.  Thus $A = 9$, $B = 15$, and $D = 36$.  Therefore our desired answer is $9\cdot 15\cdot 4\cdot 36 = \boxed{19440}$.
chatgpt_solution:
We know that $A+3 = B-3$, so $A=B-6$.  Since $AB \ne 0$, we can use the equation $A+B+C+D=64$ to solve for $D$: \begin{align*}
A+B+C+D&=64\\
A+(A+6)+(3A)+(9A)&=64\\
14A+6&=64\\
14A&=58\\
A&=58/14 = 29/7
\end{align*} If $A=29/7$, then $B=A+6 = 29/7+42/7 = 71/7$.  We know that $C=3A=3(29/7) = 87/7$.  Finally, we have  \[D = \left(\frac{A+3}{3}\right) = \left(\frac{29/7+3}{3}\right) = \frac{58/7}{3} = \frac{58}{21}.\]Thus \[ABCD = \left(\frac{29}{7}\right)\left(\frac{71}{7}\right)\left(\frac{87}{7}\right)\left(\frac{58}{21}\right) = \frac{29 \cdot 71 \cdot 87 \cdot 58}{7 \cdot 7 \cdot 7 \cdot 21} = \frac{29\cdot 71\cdot 87 \cdot 2^{1} \cdot 29 \cdot 3^{2}}{7^{4}}.\]The prime factorization of $ABC$ contains two of the prime factor of $7$, and there is only one factor of $7$ in the denominator, so we can cancel once, leaving \[ABCD = \frac{29\cdot 71\cdot 87 \cdot 2 (29)(3^{2})}{7^{2}} = \frac{2\cdot 29^{2} \cdot 71 \cdot 87}{7^2} = \frac{2\cdot 29^{2} \cdot 71 \cdot 3^{2} \cdot 29}{7^{2}} = \boxed{2\cdot 29^{2} \cdot 71 \cdot 9 \cdot 29}.\]
